Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) Spectrometer for Research and Education in Chemistry and Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program, Professor Luis Echegoyen from the University of Texas El Paso and colleagues Juan Noveron, Michael Eastman, Cristian Botez and Dino Villagran will acquire an electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) synthesis of and sampling the highest occupied and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (HOMO and LUMO) of endohedral metallofullerenes (EMFs) and their derivatives; (b) parallel proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) with dimolybdenum bimetallic units; (c) understanding the electronic structure of Ru2(5+) dimers; (d) coordination chemistry of paramagnetic centers in metal-organic supramolecular nanomaterials; (e) cyanide polymers; and (f) magnetic behavior of metal oxide nanoparticle ensembles.

EPR spectrometers detect electrons, more specifically, the energy necessary to excite an electron to a higher quantized energy state. This occurs when the spectrometer provides the energy necessary to flip the spin of an unpaired electron in the presence of an applied magnetic field. This information provides insight into the electronic structure and bonding of the material being studied, which can be utilized to understand its properties and how it might be used or improved. This spectrometer will provide faculty and research students with modern instrumentation not currently available at the institution advancing their research projects significantly. It will be used in an undergraduate laboratory course providing training in this analytical technique to large numbers of Hispanic-American students at an institution with a 78% undergraduate student body of Hispanic origin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectrometer was purchased with NSF funds to fill an important research need at the University of Texas at El Paso and the surrounding area, including New Mexico and vicinities. The closest functional EPR spectrometer before the acquisition was at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque, 270 miles away, and a comparable one to the one purchased under this grant was located even farther away, in Tucson, 340 miles away. The instrument has been made available to researchers at New Mexico State University in Las Cruces, as well as to researchers at the medical school of Texas Tech, which is located in El Paso. While not many specific projects from outside UTEP have used the EPR spectrometer, the facility is open to them.

 

EPR spectroscopy is a specialized technique that can detect unpaired electrons in molecules and materials and provide detailed information as to the location of these electrons as well as the environment around them. Four research groups at UTEP have used the newly acquired instrument to study a variety of new systems, that range from endohedral fullerenes to dimetallic units bound by a variety of ligands, probing the electronic properties of the unpaired electrons. Endohedral fullerenes are carbon cages that contain clusters of other atoms trapped inside which alter their electronic properties and some of these have been shown to be potentially useful and important in solar cells. The EPR spectrometer has allowed UTEP researchers to probe the fundamental electronic properties of some of these new compounds and to design new systems for better performance based on the observations. The instrument has also allowed the analysis of the electronic structure of Ru25+ and W22+ bimetallic units interacting with different ligands. It has also allowed researchers in the Physics Department at UTEP to investigate magnetite nanoparticles, in particular to probe their so-called superspin dynamics, which is a fundamental property to understand and control the overall magnetic behavior of an ensemple of these nanoparticles. Still another group working with copper and iron nanoparticles encapsulated in gel matrices has been able to probe their electronic properties, and these are potentially useful for specific ion removal for water remediation. A provisional patent has been submitted resulting from this work and is currently under review. In addition to this patent application, three articles acknowledging this grant have been published.

Besides the impact on the city of El Paso (mainly to UTEP and Texas Tech Medical School) and the surrounding areas (NMSU at Las Cruces) this instrument has had a major impact due to its incorporation in the undergraduate curriculum at UTEP. Undergraduate students, who are primarily of Hispanic descent and first generation college goers, are now being exposed to an important research technique that was previously not available. This adds an extra dimension to their education and makes them more knowledgable and competitive in the work force.
